Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: An Individualized 3D Printed Silicone Bottle Nipple
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is improved health and economic impact as a result of a 3D printing technology, combined with fluid dynamic modeling, that has the potential to prolong breastfeeding. An individualized, 3D printed silicone bottle nipple, that closely mimics a mother's breast, creates continuity between bottle and breast, reducing the primary barrier to breastfeeding, nipple confusion. Prolonged breastfeeding and skin to skin contact enables breast milk to continually act in establishing immunity, enabling protective neurological development, and genetic optimization through microbiome establishment. The core technology of this project has a commercialization potential to solve issues mothers face every day and the global societal impact of the innovation could be substantial. It is projected that increasing rates of breastfeeding could save the lives of more than 820,000 children under age five, annually, prevent 20,000 breast cancer deaths, while saving $300 billion annually in health care costs worldwide.

This I-Corps project aims to evaluate the commercialization potential of a baby bottle nipple concept which replicates a mother's nipple in terms of shape and texture while matching the flow rate to that of the maternal flow rate. One of the intellectual merits of the innovation is its individualized 3D printed silicone bottle nipple which addresses nipple confusion related to shape based on a 3D survey of a mother's nipples. The 3D scanning technology allows mothers to use an application to scan their breasts to be able to select which 3D printed mold fits their breasts the best, leading to seamless bottle to breast continuity. The innovation also appropriately addresses nipple confusion related to flow rate in its design. The team conducted fluid dynamics analyses to determine the flow rate through the printed nipple that matches the flow rate from a small data set from preterm mothers. The core technology has the potential to allow better continuity between the breast and bottle, help enable mothers to overcome the barriers they face so they can continue breastfeeding for the recommended minimum of 2 years.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The extensive eight weeks long I-Corps project aimed to evaluate the commercialization potential of a baby bottle nipple concept which replicates a mother's nipple in terms of shape and texture while matching the flowrate to that of the maternal flowrate.  This allows for better continuity between the breast and bottle, help enable mothers to overcome the barriers they face so they can continue breastfeeding for the recommended minimum of 2 years.

As presented during the "Lessons Learned" workshop, the Entrepreneurial Lead reported over a hundred interviews held during the program.  These interviews were with a clinician, lactation consultants, nursing administrator, nurse manager, competitor, expecting mothers, breastfeeding mothers, mothers of Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) infants, and mothers who want to continue breastfeeding upon returning to work. NSF I-Corps Team program benefited learning business development and marketing strategies on how to successfully achieve the introduction of the baby bottle into the breastfeeding accessories market.

Early in the program, the interviews conducted by the Entrepreneurial Lead led to invalidate one of the leading hypotheses as the customer of the nursing products seems to be indifferent to maternal flow rate and nipple shape. However, nipple confusion was reported to be a common trend in multiple instances. One of the major pivots is done by the middle of the program when the Entrepreneurial Lead discovered from the interviews that the hospital readmittance of infants is poorly tracked and increased hospital cost. An important metric to help assess when the baby is ready to be discharged is reported to be the free flow drip rate. Hence, the new hypothesis was determined as controlling flow rate allows babies to feed independently sooner and reduce extended stay costs to the hospital. The I-Corps program also benefited in obtaining the market size of breastfeeding accessories as well as a petal diagram.

At the end of the eight weeks long NSF I-Corps program, the technology investigated was determined as a "go" with the pivot discussed earlier. The Business Model Canvas, formulated during the NSF I-Corps Teams program, has served as the basis for Ms. Lauren Wright, creating a startup independently and formed a small business which is currently seeking funding via various avenues.

 


Last Modified: 06/03/2019
Modified by: Rasim Guldiken
